newsitem.title: USA: Informix turns to outside tools vendors.
newsitem.headline: Informix turns to outside tools vendors.

text.p: Informix Corp, revamping the weakest part of its software business, said Monday it will let customers use application development tools from other companies, including rivals.

Informix, based in Menlo Park, Calif., writes computer programs, called databases, that stores and retrieves huge amounts of corporate information. Customers use other computer programs, called development tools, to write custom software to put in and take out information from these databases.

The company said customers can now use popular and cheap application development tools from companies such as Microsoft Corp, Symantec Corp and Powersoft Corp, a unit of rival database vendor Sybase Inc. Millions of programmers already use these tools to write commercial- quality programs and make World Wide Web pages.
Until now, Informix customers could write custom applications for Informix databases only with Informix's relatively expensive and esoteric New Era development tools.

The strategy will make it easier for customers to write software for Informix databases, which could lead to higher sales of Informix's flagship Universal Server database product, said Brett Bachman, Informix general manager of enterprise products.
"We expect it to yield dramatic increases in revenue associated with Universal Server," Bachman said.

The strategy also would free up Informix's research and development efforts to concentrate on its core products, analysts said. New Era has accounted for a decreasing share of Informix's total revenue in recent quarters because of weak sales.
Informix said customers can use Microsoft's Visual Basic or Java-based development tools -- which cost as little as $100 -- to write applications for its databases.
The company also said it will continue to sell its own New Era development tools for $4,495.
